play.title:
THE
Tragedie of King
Richard the ſecond.

persona.persname: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster
Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

play.title:
Enter King Richard, Iohn
of Gaunt, with other Nobles
and Attendants.

speech.speaker: King Richard.
speech.line: OLde Iohn of Gaunt, time honoured Lancaﬅer;
Haﬅ thou according to thy oth and band,
Brought hither Henrie Herford thy bold ſonne,
Here to make good the boyﬅrous late appeale
Which then our leiſure would not let vs heare
Againﬅ the Duke of Norfolke, Thomas Mowbray?

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: I haue my Liege.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Tell me moreouer; haﬅ thou ſounded him
If he appeale the Duke on auncient malice,
Or worthily, as a good ſubieƈt ſhould,
On ſome knowne ground of treacherie in him?

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: As neare as I could ﬁft him on that argument,
On ſome apparant danger ſeene in him,
Aimde at your Highneﬀe; no inueterate malice.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Then call them to our preſence face to face,
And frowning brow to brow our ſelues will heare
The accuſer, and the accuſed, freely ſpeake:
Hie ﬅomackt are they both, and full of ire,
In rage, deafe as the ſea, haﬅie as fire.

speech.speaker: Bulling.
speech.line: Many yeares of happy dayes befall
My gratious Soueraigne, my moﬅ louing Liege.

speech.speaker: Mowb.
speech.line: Each day ﬅill better others happineﬀe,
Vntill the Heauens enuying Earths good happe,
Adde in immortall title to your Crowne.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Wee thanke you both: yet one but flatters vs,
As well appeareth by the cauſe you come;
Namely, to appeale each other of high treſon.
Cooﬁn of Hereford, what doﬅ thou obieƈt
Againﬅ the Duke of Norfolke Thomas Mowbray?

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Firﬅ (heauen be the record to my ſpeech)
In the deuotion of a ſubieƈtes loue,
Tendring the precious ſafetie of my Prince,
And free from other misbegotten hate,
Come I appeallant to this princely preſence.
Now Thomas Mowbray, do I turne to thee;
And marke my greeting well: for what I ſpeake,
My body ſhall make good vpon this earth,
Or my diuine ſoule anſwere it in heauen.
Thou art a Traytor, and a miſcreant;
Too good to be ſo and too bad to liue:
Since the more faire and criﬅall is the skie,
The vglier ſeeme the cloudes that in it flie.
Once more, the more to agrauate the note,
With a foule traytours name ﬅuffe I thy throate,
And wiſh (ſo pleaſe my Soueraigne) ere I moue,
What my tong ſpeaks, my right drawne ſword may proue.

speech.speaker: Mowb.
speech.line: Let not my cold wordes here accuſe my zeale.
Tis not the tryall of a Womans warre,
The bitter clamor of two eager tongues,
Can arbitrate this cauſe betwixt vs twaine:
The blood is hotte that muﬅ be coold for this,
Yet can I not of ſuch tame patience boaﬅ,
As to be huſht and naught at all to ſay.
Firﬅ the faire reuerence of your highneﬀe curbes me,
From giuing reynes and ſpurres to my free ſpeech,
Which elſe would poﬅ vntill it had returnd
Theſe tearmes of treaſon doubled downe his throat;
Setting a ﬁde his high bloods royaltie:
And let him be no kinſman to my Leige,
I doe defie him, and ſpit at him;
Call him a ﬂaunderous Coward and a Villaine:
Which to maintaine, I would allow him ods,
And meete him, were I tide to runne a foote,
Euen to the frozen ridges of the Alpes,
Or any other ground inhabitable,
Where euer Engliſh man durﬅ ſet his foote.
Meane time, let this defend my loyaltie,
By all my hopes, moﬅ falﬂy doth he lie.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Pale trembling Coward, there I throw my gage,
Diſclayming here the kinred of a King,
And lay aﬁde my high bloods royaltie;
Which feare, not reuerence makes thee to except.
If guiltie dread haue left thee ſo much ﬅrength,
As to take vp mine honours pawne, then ﬅoope:
By that, and all the rites of Knighthood elſe,
Will I make good againﬅ thee arme to arme,
What I haue ſpoke, or what thou canﬅ deuiſe.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: I take it vp, and by that Sword I ſweare,
Which gently layde my Knighthood on my ſhoulder,
Ile anſwere thee in any faire degree:
Or chiualrous deﬁgne of Knightly tryall.
And when I mount aliue, aliue may I not light,
If I be Traitour, or vniuﬅly fight.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What doth our Cooﬁn lay to Mowbraies charge?
It muﬅ be great that can inherite vs,
So much as of a thought of ill in him.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Looke what I ſayd, my life ſhall prooue it true,
That Mowbray hath receiude eight thouſand Nobles,
In name of lendinges, for your Highneﬀe Souldiours:
The which he hath detainde for leawd imployments,
Like a falſe Traytour, and iniurious Villaine.
Beﬁdes I ſay, and will in battaile prooue,
Or here, or elſe where, to the furtheﬅ Verge
That euer was ſurueyed by Engliſh eye,
That all the treaſons for theſe eighteene yeares,
Complotted and contriued in this Land,
Fetcht from falſe Mowbray, their firﬅ head and ſpring:
Further I ſay, and further will maintaine
Vpon his bad life to make all this good,
That he did plotte the Duke of Gloﬅers death,
Suggeﬅ his ſoone beleeuing aduerſaries,
And conſequently like a Traitour Coward,
Slucte out his innocent ſoule through ﬅreames of blood:
Which blood, like ſacrificing Abels, cryes,
Euen from the tongueleﬀe Cauerns of the earth,
To me for iuﬅice, and rough chaﬅiſement:
And by the glorious worth of my diſcent,
This Arme ſhall do it, or this Life be ſpent.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: How high a pitch his reſolution ſoares:
Thomas of Norfolke, what ſayﬅ thou to this?

speech.speaker: Mowb.
speech.line: Oh let my Soueraigne turne away his face,
And bid his eares a little while be deafe,
Till I haue told this ﬂaunder of his blood,
How God, and good men, hate ſo foule a lyer.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Mowbray, impartiall are our eyes and eares;
Were he my Brother; nay, my kingdomes Heire,
As he is but my fathers brothers Sonne,
Now by Scepters awe I make a vow,
Such neighbour neerenes to our ſacred blood,
Should nothing priuiledge him, nor partialize
The vnﬅooping firmeneﬀe of my vpright ſoule:
He is our ſubieƈt Mowbray, ſo art thou,
Free ſpeech and feareleﬀe I to thee allow.

speech.speaker: Mowb.
speech.line: Then Bullingbrooke, as low as to thy heart,
Through the falſe paﬀage of thy throat thou lyeﬅ:
Three partes of that receipt I had for Callice,
Disburﬅ I to his highneﬀe Souldiours;
The other part reſeru’de I, by conſent,
For that my Soueraigne liege was in my debt,
Vpon remainder of a deare account,
Since laﬅ I went to France to fetch his Queene:
Now ſwallow downe that lie. For Gloceﬅers death:
I ﬂew him not, but to mine owne diſgrace
Negleƈted my ſworne duetie in that caſe:
For you my noble Lord of Lancaƈter,
The honourable Father to my foe,
Once did I lay an ambuſh for your life;
A treſpaﬀe that doth vexe my greeued ſoule:
Ah, but ere I laﬅ receiu’de the Sacrament,
I did confeﬀe it, and exaƈtly begd
Your Graces pardon, and I hope I had it.
This is my fault; as for the reﬅ appeald,
It iﬀues from the rancour of a Villaine,
A recreant, and moﬅ degenerate Traitour;
Which in my ſelfe I boldly will defend,
And enterchangeably hurle downe the gage,
Tpon this ouerweening traitours foote,
To prooue my ſelfe a loyall Gentleman,
Euen in the beﬅ blood chamberd in his boſome:
In haﬅe whereof, moﬅ hartily I pray
Your highneﬀe to aﬃgne our triall day.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Wrath kindled Gentleman, be ruled by me,
Lets purge this choler without letting bloud,
This we preſcribe, though no Phiﬁtion:
Deepe Malice makes too deepe inciﬁon:
Forget, forgiue; conclude, and be agreed,
Our Doƈtors ſay, this is no month to bleed:
Good Vnckle, let this end, where it begunne;
Weele calme the Duke of Norfolke, you your ſonne.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: To be a make-peace, ſhall become my age:
Throw downe (my ſonne) the Duke of Norfolkes gage.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And Norfolke, throw downe his.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: When Harrie, when? obedience bids,
Obedience bids I ſhould not bid againe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Norfolke, throw downe we bid, there is no boote.

speech.speaker: Mowb.
speech.line: My ſelfe I throw (dread ſoueraigne) at thy foote,
My life thou ſhalt commaund, but not my ſhame:
The one my duetie owes; but my faire name,
Deſpight of Death that liues vpon my Graue,
To darke Diſhonours vſe, thou ſhalt not haue:
I am diſgraﬅe, impeacht, and baffuld heere;
Pierﬅ to the ſoule with Slaunders venomd ſpeare,
The which no Balme can cure, but his heart blood
Which breathde this poyſon.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Rage muﬅ be withﬅood:
Giue me his gage; Lions make Leopards tame.

speech.speaker: Mowb.
speech.line: Yea, but not change his ſpots; take but my ſhame,
And I reﬁgne my gage, my deare deare Lord.
The pureﬅ treaſure mortall times affoord,
Is ſpotleﬀe reputation, that away;
Men are but guilded Loame, or painted Clay:
A Iewell in a tenne times bard vp Cheﬅ,
Is a bold Spirit in a loyall Breaﬅ.
Mine Honour is my life, both grow in one;
Take Honour from me, and my life is done.
Then (deare my Leige) mine Honour let me try,
In that I liue, and for that will I die.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Cooﬁn, throw vp your gage; do you begin.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: O God, defend my ſoule from ſuch deepe ﬁnne,
Shall I ſeeme Creﬅ-fallen in my fathers ﬁght?
Or with pale begger-face impeach my hight,
Before this out-darde daﬅard? Ere my tongue
Shall wound my Honour with ſuch feeble vvrong,
Or ſound ſo baſe a parlee, my teeth ſhall teare
The ﬂauiſh motiue of recanting feare,
And ſpit it bleeding in his high diſgrace,
Where ſname doth harbour, euen in Mowbraies face.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: We were not borne to ſue, but to commaund;
Which ﬁnce we can not do, to make you friendes,
Be ready (as your life ſhall anſwere it)
At Couentrie vpon Saint Lambards day:
There ſhall your Swords and Launces arbitrate
The ſwelling difference of your ſetled hate:
Since we cannot atone you, you ſhall ſee
Iuﬅice deﬁgne the Viƈtors chiualrie.
Lord Marſhall, commaund our Officers at Armes,
Be readie to direƈt theſe home allarmes.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Iohn of Gaunt, with the Dutcheﬀe of Glouceﬆer.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Alas, the part I had in Woodﬅocks blood,
Doth more ſollicite me, then your exclaimes,
To ﬅirre againﬅ the butchers of his life.
But ﬁnce correƈtion lyeth in thoſe handes,
Which made the fault that we connot correƈt,
Put we our quarrell to the will of heauen;
Who when they ſee the hower’s ripe on earth,
Will rains hot vengeance on offenders heades.

speech.speaker: Dutcheße.
speech.line: Findes brotherhood in thee no ſharper ſpurre?
Hath loue in thy old blood no liuing fire?
Edwards ſeauen ſonnes, whereof thy ſelfe art one,
Were ſeauen Viols of his ſacred blood,
Or ſeauen faire Branches ſpringing from one roote:
Some of thoſe Branches by the Deﬅinies cut:
But Thomas my deare Lord, my life, my Gloceﬆer,
One Violl full of Edwards ſacred blood,
One flouriſhing Branch of his moﬅ royall roote
Is craƈt, and all the precious liquor ſpilt,
Is hackt downe, and his ſummer leaues all faded
By Enuies hand, and Murders bloodie axe.
Ah Gaunt, his blood was thine, that bed, that wombe,
That mettall, that ſelfe mould, that faſhioned thee,
Made him a man: and though thou liueﬅ and breatheﬅ,
Yet art thou ﬂaine in him; thou doﬅ conſent
In ſome large meaſure to thy fathers death,
In that thou ſeeﬅ thy wretched Brother die,
Who was the modell of thy fathers life:
Call it not Patience, Gaunt, it is Diſpaire,
In ſuffering thus thy Brother to be ﬂaughtred;
Thou ſheweﬅ the naked pathway to thy life,
Teaching ﬅerne Murder how to butcher thee:
That which in meane men we intitle Patience,
Is pale cold Cowardice in Noble breaﬅes.
What ſhall I ſay? to ſafegard thy owne life,
The beﬅ way is, to venge my Gloceﬅers death.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Gods is the quarrell, for Gods ſubﬅitute,
His deputie annoynted in his ﬁght,
Hath cauſd his death; the which if wrongfully,
Let Heauen reuenge, for I may neuer lift
An angrie arme againﬅ his miniﬅer.

speech.speaker: Duch.
speech.line: Where then alas may I complaine my ſelfe?

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: To God, the Widowes Champion and defence.

speech.speaker: Duch.
speech.line: Why then I will: farewell old Gaunt,
Thou goeﬅ to Couentry, there to behold
Our Cooﬁn Herford and fell Mowbray fight.
O ſet my husbands wronges on Herfords Speare,
That it may enter butcher Mowbraies breaﬅ.
Or if misfortune miﬀe the firﬅ carrier,
Be Mowbraies ﬁnnes ſo heauie in his boſome,
That they may breake his foming Courſers backe,
And throw the rider headlong in the liﬅes,
A catiue recreant to my Cooﬁn Herford.
Farewell old Gaunt, thy ſometimes brothers wife,
With her companion, griefe muﬅ end her life,

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Siﬅer farewell, I muﬅ to Couentrie:
As much good ﬅay with thee, as goe with me.

speech.speaker: Duch.
speech.line: Yet one word more; griefe boundeth where it falles
Not with the emptie hollowneﬀe, but weight:
I take my leaue before I haue begunne,
For ſorrow endes not when it ſeemeth done:
Commende me to my brother Edmund Yorke:
Loe this is all: nay yet depart not ſo,
Though this be all, do not ſo quickly goe,
I ſhall remember more: Bidd him; ah what?
With all good ſpeed at Plaſhie viﬁt me.
Alacke and what ſhall good old Yorke there ſee,
But emptie Lodgings and vnfurniſht Walles,
Vnpeopled Offices, vntrodden Stones,
And what heare there for welcome, but my grones?
Therefore commend me, let him not come there,
To ſeeke out ſorrow, that dwels euery where;
Deſolate, deſolate will I hence and die:
The laﬅ leaue of thee takes my weeping eye.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter the Lord Marſhall and the Duke Aumerle.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My Lord Aumerle, is Harry Kerford armde?

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Yea at all poyntes, and longs to enter in.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The Duke of Norfolke ſprightfully and bold,
Staies but the ſummons of the appellants trumpet.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Why then the Champions are prepard, and ﬅay
For no thing but his Maieﬅies approach.

sceneref.stagedir: The trumpets ſound, and the King enters with his Nobles: when they are ſet, enter the Duke of Norfolke in armes defendant.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Marſhall demaund of yonder Champion,
The cauſe of his ariuall here in armes,
Aske him his name, and orderly proceede
To ſweare him in the iuﬅice of his cauſe.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: In Gods name and the Kinges, ſay who thou art,
And why thou commeﬅ thus Knightly clad in armes?
Againﬅ what man thou comﬅ, and what’s thy quarrell,
Speake truely on thy Knighthood, and thy oth,
As ſo defend thee heauen and thy valour

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: My name is Thomas Mowbray, D. of Norfolke,
Who hither come ingaged by my oath,
(Which God defend a Knight ſhould violate)
Both to defend my loyaltie and truth,
To God, my King, and my ſucceeding iﬀue,
Againﬅ the Duke of Herford that appeales mee,
And by the grace of God, and this mine arme,
To prooue him in defending of my ſelfe,
A Traitour to my God, my King, and me:
And as I truly fight, defend me heauen.

sceneref.stagedir: The Trumpets ſound, enter Duke of Herford appellant in armour

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Marſhall aske yonder Knight in armes,
Both who he is, and why he commeth hither
Thus plated in habillements of Warre,
And formally, according to our law,
Depoſe him in the iuﬅice of his cauſe.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: What is thy name, & wherefore comﬅ thou hither,
Before King Richard in his royall liﬅs?
Againﬅ whom comes thou? and what’s thy quarrell?
Speake like a true Knight, ſo defend thee Heauen.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Harry of Herford, Lancaﬅer, and Darbie
Am I, who readie heere do ﬅand in Armes,
To prooue by Gods grace, and my bodies valour
In liﬅs, on Thomas Mowbray Duke of Norfolke,
That he is a Traitour foule and dangerous,
To God of heauen, King Richard, and to me:
And as I truly fight, defend me heauen.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: On paine of death no perſon be ſo bolde
Or daring, hardie, as to touch the liﬅs,
Except the Martiall and ſuch officers
Appointed to direƈt theſe faire deﬁgnes.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Lord Martiall, let me kiﬀe my Soueraignes hand.
And bow my knee before his Maieﬅie,
For Mowbray and my ſelfe are like two men,
That vow along and wearie pilgrimage.
Then let vs take a ceremonious leaue,
And louing farewell of our ſeuerall friends.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The appellant in all dutie greetes your highneﬀe,
And craues to kiﬀe your hand and take his leaue.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: We will deſcend and folde him in our armes.
Cooﬁn of Herford, as thy cauſe is right,
So be thy fortune in this royall fight:
Farewell my bloud, which if to day thou ſhead,
Lament we may, but not reuenge thee dead.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: O let no noble eie prophane a teare
For me, if I be gorde with Mowbrayes ſpeare:
As confident as is the Falcons flight
Againﬅ a bird, do I with Mowbray fight.
My louing Lord I take my leaue of you:
Of you (my noble Cooﬁn) Lord Aumarle,
Not ﬁcke, although I haue to do with death,
But luﬅie, yong, and cheerely drawing breath.
Loe, as at Engliſh feaﬅs ſo I regreet
The daintieﬅ laﬅ, to make the end moﬅ ſweete.
Oh thou the earthly Author of my bloud,
Whoſe youthfull ſpirit in me regenerate,
Doth with a two-folde vigour lift me vp,
To reach a viƈtorie aboue my head,
Adde proofe vnto mine armour with thy prayers,
And with thy bleﬃngs ﬅeele my launces point,
That it may enter Mowbrayes waxen coate,
And furbiſh new the name of Iohn a Gaunt,
Euen in the luﬅie hauiour of his Sonne.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: God in thy good cauſe make thee proſperous.
Be ſwift like lightning in the execution,
And let thy blowes doubly redoubled,
Fall like amazing thunder on the caske
Of thy aduerſe pernitious enemie,
Rowſe vp thy youthfull bloud, be valiant and liue.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Mine innocence and Saint George to thriue.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: How euer God or fortune caﬅ my lotte,
There lies or dies true to King Richards throne,
A loyall, iuﬅ, and vpright Gentleman:
Neuer did captiue with a freer heart
Caﬅ off his Chaines of Bondage, and embrace,
His Golden vncontroled Enfranchiſement,
More then my dauncing ſoule doth celebrate
This feaﬅ of battle with mine aduerſarie.
Moﬅ mightie Liege, and my companion Peeres,
Take from my mouth the wiſh of happie yeares,
As gentle and as iocund as to ieﬅ,
Goe I to fight, truth hath a quiet breﬅ.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Farewell (my Lord) ſecurely I eſpie,
Vertue with valour couched in thine eie,
Order the triall Martiall and beginne.

speech.speaker: Mart.
speech.line: Harrie of Herforde, Lancaﬅer, and Darby,
Receiue thy launce, and God defend thy right.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Strong as a tower in hope I cry, Amen.

speech.speaker: Mart.
speech.line: Go beare this launce to Thomas D. of Norfolke.

speech.speaker: Herald.
speech.line: Harry of Herford, Lancaﬅer, and Darby
Stands heere, for God, his Soueraigne, and himſelfe,
On paine to be found falſe and recreant,
To proue the Duke of Norfolke Thomas Mowbray
A Traitour to his God, his King, and him.
And dares him to ſet forwards to the fight.

speech.speaker: Her.
speech.line: Here ﬅandeth Thomas Mowbray D. of Norfolke,
On paine to be found falſe and recreant,
Both to befend himſelfe, and to approue
Henry of Herford, Lancaﬅer, and Darby,
To God, his Soueraigne, and to him diﬂoyall,
Couragiouﬂy, and with a free deﬁre,
Attending but the ﬁgnall to begin.

speech.speaker: Mart.
speech.line: Sound Trumpets, and ſet foorth Combatants:
Stay, the King hath throwne his warder downe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Let them lay by their Helmets, and their Speares,
And both returne backe to their Chaires againe:
Withdraw with vs, and let the Trumpets ſound,
While we returne theſe Dukes what we decree.
Draw neere and liﬅ
What with our Counſell we haue done.
For that our kingdomes earth ſhould not be ſoyld
With that deare blood which it hath foﬅered:
And for our eyes do hate the dire aſpeƈt
Of ciuill wounds ploughd vp with neighbours ſword:
And for we thinke the Eagle-winged pride
Of skie-aſpiring and ambitious thoughts
With riual-hating Enuie ſet on you,
To wake our peace, which in our Countries cradle
Drawes the ſweete infant breath of gentle ﬂeepe,
Which ſo rouzd vp vvith boyﬅerous vntunde drummes,
With harſh reſounding trumpets dreadfull bray,
And grating ſhock of vvrathfull yron armes,
Might from our quiet confines fright faire Peace,
And make vs vvade euen in our kinreds blood:
Therefore vve baniſh you our territories.
You Cooﬁn Herford, vpon paine of life,
Till tvvice fiue Summers haue enricht our field,
Shall not regreete our faire dominions,
But tread the ﬅranger pathes of baniſhment.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Your vvill be done; this muﬅ my comfort be,
That Sunne that vvarmes you heere, ſhall ſhine on me;
And thoſe his golden beames vnto you heere lent,
Shall poynt on me, and guild my baniſhment.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Norfolke, for thee remaines a heauier doome,
Which I with ſome vnwillingnes pronounce,
The ﬂie ﬂow houres ſhall not determinate
The dateleﬀe limit of thy deare exile:
The hopeleﬀe word of neuer to returne,
Breath I againﬅ thee, vpon paine of life.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: A heauie ſentence, my moﬅ ſoueraigne Liege,
And all vnlookt for from your Highnes mouth.
A dearer merit, not ſo deepe a mayme,
As to be caﬅ foorth in the common ayre,
Haue I deſerued at your Highneﬀe hands:
The language I haue learnd theſe fourty yeares,
My natiue Engliſh now I muﬅ forgoe,
And now my tongues vſe is to me no more
Than an vnﬅringed violl or a harpe,
Or like a cunning inﬅaument caſde vp,
Or being open, put into his hands
That knowes no touch to tune the harmony.
Within my mouth you haue ingaylde my tongue,
Doubly perculliﬅ with my teeth and lippes,
And dull vnfeeling barren ignorance
Is made my Iayler to attende on me:
I am too old to fawne vpon an Nurſe,
Too farre in yeares to be a Pupill now.
What is thy ſentence but ſpeechleﬀe death;
Which robbes my tongue from breathing natiue breath?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: It bootes thee not to be compaſsionate,
After our ſentence, playning comes too late.

speech.speaker: Mowb.
speech.line: Then thus I turne me from my Countries light,
To dwell in ſolemne ſhades of endleﬀe night.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Returne againe, and take an oth with thee,
Lay on our royall Svvord your baniſht hands.
Svveare by the dutie that y’ovve to God,
(Our part therein vve baniſh vvith your ſelues)
To keepe the oath that vve adminiﬅer:
You neuer ſhall, ſo helpe you truth and God,
Embrace each others loue in baniſhment,
Nor neuer looke vpon each others face,
Nor neuer vvrite, regreete, nor reconcile,
This louing tempeﬅ of your home-bred hate,
Nor neuer by aduiſed purpoſe meete,
To plotte, contriue, or complot any ill,
Gainﬅ vs, our ﬅate, our ſubieƈts, or our land.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: I ſweare.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: And I, to keepe all this.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Norfolke, ſo fare as to mine enemie:
By this time, had the King permitted vs,
One of our ſoules had wandred in the ayre,
Baniſht this frayle Sepulchre of our fleſh,
As not our fleſh is baniſht from this land.
Confeﬀe thy treaſons ere thou fly the Realme,
Since thou haﬅ farre to go, beare not along
The cloging burthen of a guiltie ſoule.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: No Bullingbrooke, if euer I were traytour,
My name be blotted from the Booke of life,
And I from Heauen baniſht, as from hence:
But what thou art, God, thou, and I, do know,
And all too ſoone (I feare) the King ſhall rew:
Farewell (my Leige) now no way can I ﬅray,
Saue backe to England, all the world’s my way.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Vncle, euen in the glaﬀes of thine eyes,
I ſee thy grieued heart: thy ſad aſpeƈt
Hath from the number of his baniſht yeares
Pluckt foure away, ﬁxe frozen Winters ſpent,
Returne with welcome home from baniſhment.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: How long a time lies in one little word?
Foure lagging Winters, and foure wanton Springs,
End in a word; ſuch is the breach of Kings.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: I thanke my Liege, that in regard of mee,
He ſhortens foure yeares of my Sonnes exile;
But little vantage ſhall I reape thereby:
For ere the ﬁxe yeares that he hath to ſpend
Can change their moones, and bring their times about,
My oyle-dried lampe, and time bewaﬅed light
Shall be extinƈt with age and endleﬀe night:
My inch of taper will be burnt and done,
And blindfold Death not let me ſee my Sonne.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why Vnckle, thou haﬅ many yeares to liue.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: But not a minute (King) that thou canﬅ giue:
Shorten my dayes thou canﬅ with ſullen ſorrow,
And plucke nights from me, but not lend a morrow.
Thou canﬅ helpe Time to furrow me with age,
But ﬅoppe no wrinckle in his pilgrimage:
Thy word is currant with him, for my death,
But dead, thy kingdome cannot buy my breath.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thy Sonne is baniſht with good aduiſe,
Whereto thy tongue, a party, verdiƈt gaue,
Why at our iuﬅice ſeemﬅ thou then to lowre?

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Things ſweete to taﬅe, prooue in digeﬅion ſowre.
You vrge me as a Iudge, but I had rather
You would haue bid me argue like a Father.
Oh had’t been a ﬅranger, not my child,
To ſmooth his fault I would haue been more milde:
A partiall ﬂaunder ſought I to auoyde,
And in the ſentence, my owne life deﬅroyde.
Alas, I lookt when ſome of you ſhould ſay,
I was too ﬅriƈt to make mine owne away:
But you gaue leaue to my vnwilling tongue,
Againﬅ my will, to do my ſelfe this wrong.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Cooﬁn farewell, and Vnckle bid him ſo;
Sixe yeares we baniſh him, and he ſhall go.

speech.speaker: Au.
speech.line: Cooﬁn farewell; what preſence muﬅ not know
From where you do remaine, let Paper ſhow,

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My Lord, no leaue take I, for I will ride
As farre as land will let me, by your ﬁde.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Oh to what purpoſe doeﬅ thou hoard thy words,
That thou returneﬅ no greeting to thy friends?

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: I haue too few to take my leaue of you,
When the tongues office ſhould be prodigall,
To breath the abundant dolour of the heart.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Thy griefe is but thy abſence for a time.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Ioy abſent, griefe is preſent for that time.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: What is ﬁxe Winters? they are quickly gone.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: To men in ioy, but griefe makes one houre ten.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Call it a trauaile that thou takﬅ for pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: My heart willl ﬁgh when I miſcall it ſo,
Which findes it an inforced pilgrimage.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: The ſullen paﬀage of thy wearie ﬅeps,
Eﬅeeme a ſoyle wherein thou art to ſet,
The previous Iewell of thy home returne.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Nay rather euerie tedious ﬅride I make,
Will but remember me what deale of world
I wander from the Iewels that I loue.
Muﬅ I not ſerue a long apprentiſhood
To forren paﬀages, and in the end,
Hauing my freedome, boaﬅ of nothing elſe,
But that I was a iourneyman to griefe?

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: All places that the eie of heauen viﬁts,
Are to a wiſeman ports and happy hauens.
Teach thy necesﬁtie to reaſon thus.
There is no vertue like necesﬁtie:
Thinke not the King did baniſh thee
But thou the King, who doth the heauier ﬁt,
Where it perceiues it is but faintly borne:
Go, ſay I ſent thee forth to purchaſe honour,
And not the King exilde thee; or ſuppoſe
Deuouring peﬅilence hangs in our aire,
And thou art flying to a freſher clime:
Looke what thy ſoule holds deere, imagine it
To ly that way thou goeﬅ, not whence thou comﬅ:
Suppoſe the ﬁnging birds muﬁtions,
The graﬀe whereon thou treadﬅ, the preſence ﬅrowde,
The flowers, faire Ladies, and thy ﬅeps, no more
Then a delightfull meaſure or a daunce,
For gnarling ſorrow hath leﬀe power to bite
The man that mocks at it and ſets it light.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Oh who can hold a fier in his hand,
By thinking on the froﬅy Caucaſus?
Or cloy the hungry edge of appetite,
By bare imagination of a feaﬅ?
Or wallow naked in December ſnow,
By thinking on fantasﬅick ſummers heat?
Oh no, the apprehenﬁon of the good
Giues but the greater feeling to the worſe:
Fell ſorrowes tooth doth neuer rancle more
Then when it bites, but lancheth not the ſoare.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Come come my ſonne, Ile bring thee on thy way,
Had I thy youth and cauſe, I would not ﬅay.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Then Englands ground farewell, ſweete ſoile adiew,
My Mother and my nurſe that beares me yet.
Where ere I wander, boaﬅ of this I can,
Though baniﬅ, yet a true borne Engliſhman.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter the King with Buſhie, &c. at one doore, and the Lord Aumarle at the other.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: We did obſerue Cooﬁn Aumarle,
How farre brought you high Herford on his way?

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: I brought high Herford, if you call him ſo,
But to the next high way, and there I left him.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And ſay, what ﬅore of parting tears were ſhed?

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Faith none for me, except the Northeaﬅ winde,
Which then blew bitterly againﬅ our face,
Awakt the ﬂeepie rewme, and ſo by chance
Did grace our hollow parting with a teare.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What ſaid your cooﬁn when you parted with him?

speech.speaker: Au.
speech.line: Farewell, and for my heart diſdained that my tongue
Should ſo prophane the word that taught me craft,
To counterfaite oppreﬃon of ſuch griefe,
That words ſeemd buried in my ſorrowes graue:
Marry would the word Farewell haue lengthned houres,
And added yeeres to his ſhort baniſhment,
He ſhould haue had a volume of farewels:
But ﬁnce it would not, he had none of me.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: He is our Cooﬁns Cooﬁn, but tis doubt,
When time ſhall call him home from baniſhment,
Whether our kinſman comes to ſee his friends.
Our ſelfe and Buſhie,
Obſerued his courtſhip to the common people,
How he did ſeeme to diue into their hearts,
With humble and familiar curteﬁe,
With reuerence he did throw away on ﬂaues,
Wooing poore Craftſmen with the craft of ſmiles,
And patient vnderbearing of his fortune,
As twere to baniſh their affeƈts with him,
Off goes his Bonnet to an Oyﬅer-wench,
A brace of Draymen bid God ſpeed him well,
And had the tribute of his ſupple knee,
With thankes my Countrey-men, my louing friends,
As were our England in reuerﬁon his,
And he our ſubieƈtes next degree in hope.

speech.speaker: Greene.
speech.line: Well, he is gone, and with him go theſe thoughts.
Now for the Rebels which ﬅand out in Ireland,
Expedient mannage muﬅ be made (my Liege)
Ere further leyſure yeeld them further meanes
For their aduantage, and your highneﬀe loﬀe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: We will our ſelfe in perſon to this Warre,
And for our Coffers, with too great a Court
And liberall larges, are growne ſomewhat light;
We are inforﬅ to farme our royall Realme,
The reuenue whereof ſhall furniſh vs:
For our affaires in hand if that come ſhort,
Our ſubﬅitutes at home ſhall haue blancke Charters,
Whereto, when they ſhall know what men are rich,
They ſhall ſubſcribe them for large ſummes of Gold,
And ſend them after to ſupply our wants,
For we will make for Ireland preſently.

sceneref.speech: Buſh. Old Iohn of Gaunt is grieuous ﬁcke, my Lord, Sodainely taken, and hath ſent poﬅ haﬅ To intreate your Maieﬅie to viﬁt him..

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Where lies he?

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: At Ely houſe.

sceneref.speech: King. Now put it (God) into the Phiﬁtions minde, To helpe him to his Graue immediatly: The lyning of his Coffers ſhall make coates, To decke our Souldiours for theſe Iriſh Warres. Come Gentlement, lets all goe viﬁt him, Pray God we may make haﬅe, and come too late: Amen..

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Iohn of Gaunt ﬁcke, with the Duke of Yorke, &c.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Will the King come, that I may breath my laﬅ,
In holſome counſell to his vnﬅayed youth?

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: Vex not your ſelfe, not ﬅriue not with your breath
For all in vaine comes counſell to his eare.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Oh, but they ſay, the tongues of dying men,
Inforce attention like deepe harmonie:
Where wordes are ſcarce, they are ſeldome ſpent in vaine,
For they breath trueth that breath their words in paine.
He that no more muﬅ ſay, is liﬅened more
Then they whom youth and eaſe hath taught to gloſe.
More are mens ends markt, then their liues before:
The ſetting Sunne, and Muﬁcke at the gloſe,
As the laﬅ taﬅe of ſweetes is ſweeteﬅ laﬅ,
Writ in remembrance, more then thinges long paﬅ.
Though Richard my liues counſell would not heare,
My deaths ſad tale may yet vndeafe his eare.

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: No, it is ﬅopt with other flattering ſounds,
As prayſes of his ﬅate: then there are found
Laſciuious Meeters, to whoﬅe venom ſound
The open eare of youth doth alwayes liﬅen.
Report of faſhions in proud Italie,
Whoſe manners ﬅill our tardie apiſh nation
Limps after in baſe imitation.
Where doth the world thruﬅ foorth a vanitie,
So it be new, there’s no reſpeƈt how vile,
That is not quickly buzd into his eares?
Then all too late comes Counſell to be heard,
Where Will doth mutinie with Wittes regard.
Direƈt not him whoſe way himſelfe will chouſe,
Tis breath thou lackﬅ, and that breath wilt thou looſe.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Mee thinkes I am a Prophet new inſpirde,
And thus expiring, do foretell of him;
His raſh fierce blaze of riot cannot laﬅ:
For violent fires ſoone burne out themſelues,
Small ſhowers laﬅ long, but ſodaine ﬅormes are ſhort:
He tires betimes, that ſpurs too faﬅ betimes.
With eager feeding food doth choke the feeder,
Light Vanitie, inſatiate cormorant.
Conſuming meanes ſoone prayes vpon it ſelfe:
This royall throne of Kings, this Sceptered Ile,
This earth of Maieﬅie, this ſeate of Mars,
This other Eden, demie Paradice,
This Foretreﬀe built by Nature for her ſelfe,
Againﬅ infeƈtion, and the hand of Warre;
This happy breede of Men, this little World,
This precious Stone ſet in the ﬁluer ſea,
Which ſerues it in the office of a Wall,
Or as a Moate defenﬁue to a houſe,
Againﬅ the enuie of leﬀe happier Lands:
This bleﬀed plotte, this Earth, this Realme, this England,
This Nurſe, this teeming wombe of royall Kings,
Feard by their breed, and famous by their birth,
Renowned in their deedes as farre from home,
For chriﬅian ſeruice and true chiualrie,
As is the Sepulchre in ﬅubborne Iewrie,
Of the worldes ranſome, bleﬀed Maries ſonne:
This land of ſuch deare ſoules, this deare deare land;
Deare for her reputation through the world,
Is now leaced out (I die pronounching it)
Like to a Tenement, or pelting Farme.
England bound in with the triumphant Sea,
Whoſe rockie ſhoare beates backe the enuious ﬁege
Of watry Neptune, is now bound in with ſhame,
With Inkie blottes, and rotten Parchment bonds.
That England that was wont to conquere others,
Hath made a ſhamefull conqueﬅ of it ſelfe:
Ah would the ſcandall vaniſht with my life,
How happy then were my enſuing death;

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: The King is come, deale mildly with his youth,
For young hot Colts being rag’de, do rage the more.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: How fares our noble Vncle Lancaﬅer?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What comfort man? how iﬅ with aged Gaunt?

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: O how that name befits my compoﬁtion,
Old Gaunt in deede, and gaunt in being old;
Within me Griefe hath kept a tedious faﬅ.
And who abﬅaines from meate, that is not gaunt?
For ﬂeeping England, long time haue I watcht;
Watching breedes leaneneﬀe, leaneneﬀe is all gaunt:
The pleaſure that ſome Fathers feede vpon,
Is my ﬅriƈt faﬅ, I meane my Childrens lookes,
And therein, faﬅing haﬅ thou made me gaunt.
Gaunt am I for the graue, gaunt as a graue,
Whoſe hollow wombe inherites nought but bones.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Can ﬁcke men play ſo nicely with their names?

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: No, miſerie makes ſport to mocke it ſelfe.
Since thou doﬅ ſeeke to kill my name in me,
O mocke my name (great King) to flatter thee.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Should dying men flatter thoſe that liue?

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: No, no; men liuing, flatter thoſe that die.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thou now a dying ſayﬅ, thou flattereﬅ me.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Oh no, thou dieﬅ, though I the ﬁcker be.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I am in health, I breath, I ſee thee ill.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Now he that made me, knowes I ſee thee ill,
Ill in my ſelfe to ſee, and in thee ſeeing ill,
Thy death-bed is no leﬀer then the land,
Wherein thou lieﬅ in reputation ﬁcke,
And thou too careleﬀe patient as thou art,
Commitﬅ thy annoynted body to the cure
Of thoſe Phiﬁtions that firﬅ wounded thee:
A thouſand Flatterers ﬁt within thy Crowne,
Whoſe compaﬀe is no bigger than thy head;
And yet inraged in ſo ſmall a verge,
The waﬅe is no whit leﬀer then thy land:
Oh had thy Grandﬁre with a Prophets eye,
Seene how his ſonnes ſonne ſhould deﬅroy his ſonnes,
From foorth thy reach he would haue laide thy ſhame,
Depoﬁng thee before thou wert poﬀeﬅ,
Which art poﬀeﬅ now to depoſe thy ſelfe.
Why Cooﬁn, wert thou regent of the world,
It were a ſhame to let this Land by Leaſe:
But for thy world enioying but this land,
Is it not more then ſhame to ſhame it ſo?
Land-lord of England art thou now not, not King,
Thy ﬅate of law is bondﬂaue to the law,
And thou.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Ah lunaticke leane-witted foole,
Preſuming on an Agues priuiledge,
Dareﬅ vvith thy frozen admonition
Make pale our cheeke, chaﬁng the royall blood
With furie from his natiue reﬁdence.
Novv by my Seates right royall maieﬅie
Wert thou not brother to great Edwards ſonne,
This tongue that runnes ſo roundly in thy head,
Should runne thy head from thy vnreuerent ſhoulders.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Oh ſpare me not my brother Edwards ſonne,
For that I was his father Edwards ſonne:
That blood already, like the Pellican,
Haﬅ thou tapt and drunkenly carowﬅ:
My brother Gloceﬅer, plaine well meaning ſoule,
Whom faire befall in heauen mongﬅ happy ſoules,
May be a preﬁdent and witnes good,
That thou reſpeƈtﬅ not ſpilling Edwards blood.
Ioyne with the preſent ﬁcknes that I haue,
And thy vnkindnes be like crooked age,
To crop at once a too long withered flower.
Liue in thy ſhame, but die not ſhame vvith thee:
Theſe Wordes hereafter, thy tormentors be:
Conuay me to my bed, then to my graue,
Loue they to liue, that loue and honor haue.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And let them die, that age and ſullens haue,
For both haﬅ thou, and both become the graue.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I do beſeech your Maieﬅie impute his words
To wayward ﬁcklynes and age in him:
He loues you on my life, and holdes you deere,
As Harry Duke of Herford, were he heere.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Right, you ſay true; as Herfords loue, ſo his:
As theirs, ſo mine, and be as it is.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: My Liege, old Gaunt commends him to your Maieﬅie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What ſayes hee?

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Nothing, all is ſayd;
His tongue is now a ﬅringleﬀe inﬅrument,
Wordes, life, and all, old Lancaﬅer hath ſpent.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Be Yorke the next that muﬅ be banckrout ſo,
Though Death be poore, it ends a mortall wo.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: The ripeﬅ Fruite firﬅ falles, and ſo doth he;
His time is ſpent, our pilgrimage muﬅ be:
So much for that. Now for our Iriſh Warres:
We muﬅ ſupplant thoſe rough rug-headed kernes,
Which liue like venome, where no venome elſe
But onely they, haue priuiledge to liue.
And for theſe great affayres do aske ſome charge,
Towards our aſsiﬅance we do ſeaze to vs,
The Plate, Coyne, Reuenues, and moueables
Whereof our Vnckle Gaunt did ﬅand poﬀeﬅ.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: How long ſhall I be patient? Ah how long
Shall tender duetie make me ſuffer wrong?
Not Gloceﬅers death, nor Herfords baniſhment,
Nor Gaunts rebukes, nor Englands priuate wrongs,
Nor the preuention of poore Bullingbrooke
About his marriage, nor my owne diſgrace,
Haue euer made me ſower my patient cheeke,
Or bend one wrinckle on my Soueraignes face:
I am the laﬅ of the noble Edwards ſonnes,
Of whom thy father Prince of Wales was firﬅ.
In Warre, was neuer Lion ragde more fierce:
In Peace, was neuer gently Lambe more milde
Then was that young and princely Gentleman:
His face thou haﬅ, for euen ſo lookt he,
Accompliſht with a number of thy houres;
But when he frowned, it was againﬅ the French,
And not againﬅ his Friendes: his noble hand
Did winne what he did ſpend, and ſpent not that
Which his triumphant Fathers hand had wonne:
His hands were guiltie of no kinred blood,
But bloody with the enemies of his kinne.
Oh Richard! Yorke is too farre gone with griefe,
Or elſe he neuer would compare betweene.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why Vnckle, whats the matter?

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: Oh my liege, pardon me if you pleaſe,
If not, I pleaſd not to be pardoned, am content with all:
Seeke you to ſeize and gripe into your hands,
The roialties and rights of baniſht Herford?
Is not Gaunt dead? and doth not Herford liue?
Was not Gaunt iuﬅ? and is not Harry true?
Did not the one deſerue to haue an heyre?
Is not his heyre a well deſeruing ſonne?
Take Herfordes rights away, and take from time
His Charters and his cuﬅomarie rights;
Let not to morrow then enſue to day:
Be not thy ſelfe; For how art thou a King,
But by faire ſequence, and ſucceﬃon?
Now afore God, God forbid I ſay true,
If you doe wrongfully ſeize Herfords right,
Call in the Letters patents that he hath
By his attournies generall to ſue
His liuery, and deny his offered homage,
You plucke a thouſand dangers on your head,
You loſe a thouſand well diſpoſed hearts,
And pricke my tender patience to thoſe thoughts,
Which honour and allegeance cannot thinke.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thinke what you will, we ſeize into our hands,
His plate, his goods, his money, and his land.

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: Ile not be by the while, nay liege farewell,
What will inſue hereof, there’s none can tell;
But by bad courſes may by vnderﬅood,
That their euents can neuer fall out good.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Go Buſhie, to the Earle of Wiltſhire ﬅraight,
Bid him repayre to vs to Ely houſe,
To ſee this buﬁneﬀe: to morrow next
We will for Ireland, and t’is time I trow;
And we create in abſence of our ſelfe,
Our Vnckle Yorke, Lord Gouernour of England;
For he is iuﬅ, and alwayes loued vs well:
Come on our Queene, to morrow muﬅ we part,
Be merry, for our time of ﬅay is short.

sceneref.stagedir: Exeunt King and Queene. Manet North.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Well Lordes, the Duke of Lancaﬅer is dead.

speech.speaker: Roße.
speech.line: And liuing too, for now his ſonne is Duke.

speech.speaker: Willough.
speech.line: Barely in title, not in reuenewes.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Richly in both, if iuﬅice had her right.

speech.speaker: Roße.
speech.line: My heart is great, but it muﬅ breake with ﬁlence,
Er’t be disburdened with a liberall tongue.

speech.speaker: Nort.
speech.line: Nay ſpeake thy mind, & let him nere ſpeak more,
That ſpeakes thy words againe to do thee harme.

speech.speaker: Willough.
speech.line: Tend’s that thou wouldﬅ ſpeake, to the D. of Hereford?
If it be ſo, out with it boldly man,
Quicke is mine eare to heare of good towards him.

speech.speaker: Roße.
speech.line: No good at all, that I can doe for him:
Vnleﬀe you call it good, to pitty him,
Bereft and gelded of his Patrimonie.

speech.speaker: Nort.
speech.line: Now afore God t’is ſhame, ſuch wrongs are borne
In him a royall Prince, and many mo
Of noble blood in this declining land:
The King is not himſelfe, but bacely led
By flatterers, and what they will informe,
Meerely in hate againﬅ any of vs all
That will the King ſeuerely proſecute,
Againﬅ vs, our liues, our children, and our heires.

speech.speaker: Roße.
speech.line: The Commons hath he pild with grieuous taxes,
And quite loﬅ their hearts. The Nobles hath he fin’d
For auncient quarrels, and quite loﬅ their hearts.

speech.speaker: Wollough.
speech.line: And dayly new exaƈtions are deuiſde,
As Blanckes, Beneuolences, and I wot not what.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: But what a Gods name doth become of this?

speech.speaker: Willo.
speech.line: Warres hath not waﬅed it; for warr’d he hath not,
But bacely yeelded vpon compromiſe,
That which his noble Aunceﬅors atchiude with blowes:
More hath he ſpent in peace, then they in Warres.

speech.speaker: Roße.
speech.line: The Earle of Wiltſhire hath the Realme in farme.

speech.speaker: Willo.
speech.line: The King’s growne banckrout like a broken man.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Reproach and deſolution hangeth ouer him.

speech.speaker: Roße.
speech.line: He hath not Money for theſe Iriſh Warres,
His burthenous taxations nothwithﬅanding,
But by the robbing of the baniſht Duke.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: His noble kinſman moﬅ degenerate King:
But Lords, we heare this fearefull tempeﬅ ﬁng,
Yet ſeeke no ſhelter to auoyde the ﬅorme.
We ſee the Winde ﬁt ſore vpon our Sayles,
And yet we ﬅrike not, but ſecurely periſh.

speech.speaker: Roﬀe.
speech.line: We ſee the very Wracke that we muﬅ ſuffer,
And vnauoyded is the danger now,
For ſuffering ſo the cauſes of our wracke.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Not ſo, euen through the hollow eyes of death,
I eſpie life peering; but I dare not ſay,
How neere the tidings of our comfort is.

speech.speaker: Wil.
speech.line: Nay let vs ſhare thy thoughts, as thou doﬅ ours.

speech.speaker: Roße.
speech.line: Be confident to ſpeake Northumberland,
We three are but thy ſelfe; and ſpeaking ſo,
Thy words are but as thoughts, therefore be bold.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Then thus: I haue from Le Port Blan
(A Bay in Brittanie) receiude intelligence,
That Harry Duke of Herforde, Raynold L. Cobham,
That late broke from the Duke of Exeter
His brother Archbiſhop late of Canterbury,
Sir Thomas Erpingham, Sir Iohn Ramﬅon,
Sir Iohn Norbery, ﬁr Robert Waterton, & Francis Coines,
All theſe, well furniſhed by the Duke of Brittaine,
With eight tall Ships, three thouſand men of Warre,
Are making hither with all due expedience,
And ſhortly meane to touch our Northern ſhore:
Perhaps they had ere this, but that they ﬅay
The firﬅ departing of the King for Ireland:
If then we ſhall ſhake off our Countries ﬂauiſh yoke,
Impe out our drowping Countries broken wing,
Redeeme from broken pawne the blemiſht Crowne,
Wipe off the duﬅ that hides our Scepters guilt,
And make high Maieﬅie looke like it ſelfe,
Away with me in poﬅ to Rauenſpurgh:
But if you faint, as fearing to do ſo,
Stay, and be ſecret, and my ſelfe will go.

speech.speaker: Roße.
speech.line: To horſe, to horſe, vrge doubts to them that feare.

speech.speaker: Willo.
speech.line: Hold out my horſe, and I will firﬅ be there.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter the Queene, Buſhie, and Bagot.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Madam, your Maieﬅie is too much ſadde,
You promiﬅ when you parted with the King,
To lay aﬁde halfe-harming heauineﬀe,
And entertaine a chearefull diſpoﬁtion.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: To pleaſe the King I did, to pleaſe my ſelfe
I cannot doo it; yet I know no cauſe
Why I ſhould welcome ſuch a gueﬅ as Griefe,
Saue bidding farewell to ſo ſweete a gueﬅ,
As my ſweete Richard: yet againe me thinkes
Some vnborne Sorrow ripe in Fortunes wombe,
Is comming towards me and my inward ſoule,
With nothing trembles, at ſome thing it grieues,
More then with parting from my Lord the King.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Each ſubﬅance of a griefe hath twenty ſhadowes,
Which ſhewes like griefe it ſelfe, but is not ſo:
For Sorrowes eyes glazed with blinding teares,
Deuides one thing entire to many obieƈts.
Like perſpeƈtiues, which rightly gazde vpon,
Shew nothing but confuﬁon, eyde awry,
Diﬅinguiſh forme: ſo your ſweete Maieﬅie,
Looking awry vpon your Lords departure,
Finde ſhapes of griefe more then himſelfe to waile,
Which lookt on as it is, is naught but ſhadowes
Of what it is not, then thrice (gracious Queene)
More then your Lordes departure weepe not, more is not ſeene,
Or if it be, tis with falſe Sorrowes eyes,
Which for things true, weepes things imaginarie.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: It may be ſo, but yet my inward ſoule
Perſwades me it is otherwiſe: how ere it be,
I cannot but be ſad; ſo heauie ſad,
As though on thinking on no thought I thinke,
Makes me with heauie nothing faint and ſrinke.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Tis nothing but conceite (my gracious Lady.)

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Tis nothing leﬀe, Conceite is ﬅill deriude
From ſome forefather Griefe, mine is not ſo;
For nothing hath begot my ſomething griefe,
Or ſomething hath the nothing that I grieue,
Tis in reuerﬁon that I do poﬀeﬀe:
But what it is, that is not yet knowne, what
I cannot name, tis nameleﬀe woe I wot.

speech.speaker: Greene.
speech.line: God ſaue your Maieﬅie, & well met Gentlemen,
I hope the King is not yet ſhipt for Ireland.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Why hopeﬅ thou ſo? tis better hope he is,
For his deﬁgnes craue haﬅe, his haﬅe good hope:
Then wherefore doﬅ thou hope he is not ſhipt?

speech.speaker: Greene.
speech.line: That he our hope might haue retirde his power,
And driuen into deſpaire an enemies hope,
Who ﬅrongly hath ſet footing in this land,
The baniſht Bullingbrooke repeales himſelfe,
And with vplifted armes is ſafe ariude at Rauenſpurgh.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Now God in heauen forbid.

speech.speaker: Greene.
speech.line: Ah Madam, tis too true; and that is worſe:
The Lord Northumberland, his young ſonne H. Piercie,
The Lords of Roﬀe, Beaumond, and Willoughby,
With all their powerfull friendes, are fled to him.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Why haue you not proclaimde Northumberland
And the reﬅ of the reuolting faƈtion, traytours?

speech.speaker: Greene.
speech.line: We haue, wherevpon the Earle of Worceﬅer
Hath broke his Staffe, reﬁgnd his Stewardſhip,
And al the houſhold ſeruants fled with him to Bullingbrook

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: So Greene, thou art the Midwife of my woe,
And Bullingbrooke my ſorrowes diſmall heire:
Not hath my ſoule brought foorth her prodigie,
And I a gaſping new deliuered mother,
Haue woe to woe, ſorrow to ſorrow ioynd.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Diſpaire not Madam.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Who ſhall hinder me?
I will diſpaire and be at enmitie
With couetous Hope, he is a flatterer,
A paraﬁte, a keeper backe of death,
Who gently would diﬀolue the bands of life,
Which falſe Hope lingers in extreamitie.

speech.speaker: Greene.
speech.line: Heere comes the Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: With ﬁgnes of Warre about his aged necke:
Oh full of carefull buﬁneﬀe are his lookes:
Vnckle, for Gods ſake ſpeake comfortable wordes.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Should I do ſo, I ſhould bely my thoughts,
Comfort’s in heauen, and we are on the earth,
Where nothing liues but croﬀes, care, and griefe.
Your Husband he is gone to ſaue farre off,
Whilﬅ others come to make him looſe at home:
Heere am I left to vnderprop his land,
Who weake with age cannot ſupport my ſelfe.
Now comes the ﬁcke houre that his ſurfet made,
Now ſhall he trie his Friendes that flattered him.

speech.speaker: Seruingman.
speech.line: My Lord, your ſonne was gone before I came,

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: He was, why ſo; go all which way it will:
The Nobles they are fled, the Commons they are cold,
And will (I feare) reuolt on Herfords ﬁde.
Sirra, get thee to Plaſhie to my ﬁﬅer Gloceﬅer,
Bid her ſend my preſently a thouſand pound,
Hold take my Ring.

speech.speaker: Seruing
speech.line: My Lord, I had forgot to tell your Lordſhip,
To day I came by and called there;
But I ſhall grieue you to report the reﬅ.

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: What i’ﬅ knaue?

speech.speaker: Seruingm.
speech.line: An houre before I came, the Dutcheﬀe died.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: God for his mercie! what a tyde of woes
Comes ruſhing on this wofull Land at once?
I know not what to doe: I would to God
(So my vntruth had not prouokt him to it)
The King had cut off my head with my brothers.
What, are there two Poﬅs diſpatcht for Ireland?
How ſhall we do for money for theſe Warres?
Come Siﬅer, Cooﬁn I would ſay; pray pardon me:
Goe fellow, get thee home, prouide ſome Carts,
And bring away the Armour that is there.
Gentlemen, will you go muﬅer men?
If I know how or which way to order theſe affayres,
Thus diſorderly thruﬅ into my hands,
Neuer beleeue mee: both are my kinſemen;
T’one is my Soueraigne, whom both my oath
And dutie bids defend: t’other againe,
Is my Kinſman, whom the King hath wrong’d,
Whom Conſcience and my Kindred bids to right.
Well, ſomewhat we muﬅ doe: come Cooﬁn,
Ile diſpoſe of you: Gentlemen, goe muﬅer vp your men,
And meete me preſently at Barckly:
I ſhould to Plaſhie too, but time will not permit:
All is vneuen, and euery thing is left at ﬁxe and ſeauen.

sceneref.stagedir: Exeunt Duke, & Queene: manent Buſhie and Greene.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: The Wind ﬁts faire for newes to go for Ireland,
But none returnes. For vs to leuie power
Proportionable to the enemie, is all vnpoſsible.

speech.speaker: Greene.
speech.line: Beﬁdes, our neereneﬀe to the King in loue,
Is neere the hate of thoſe loue not the King.

speech.speaker: Bag.
speech.line: And that is the wauering Commons; for their loue
Lies in their Purſes, and who ſo empties them,
By ſo much filles their hearts with deadly hate.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Wherein the King ﬅands generally condemn’d.

speech.speaker: Bag.
speech.line: If iudgement lie in them, then ſo do we,
Becauſe we euer haue been neere the King.

speech.speaker: Greene.
speech.line: Well, I will for refuge ﬅraight to Briﬅ Caﬅle,
The Earle of Wiltſhire is already there.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Thither will I with you, for little office
Will the hatefull Commons performe for vs,
Except like Curres, to teare vs all in peeces:
Will you goe along with vs?

speech.speaker: Bag.
speech.line: No, I will to Ireland to his Maieﬅie:
Farewoll, if hearts preſages be not vaine,
We three heere part, that nere ſhall meete againe.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Thats as Yorke thriues to beat backe Bullingbrook.

speech.speaker: Greene.
speech.line: Alas poore Duke, the taske he vndertakes,
Is numbring Sands, and drinking Oceans dry,
Where one on his ﬁde fights, thouſands will flie:
Farewell at once, for once, for all and euer.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Well, we may meete againe.

speech.speaker: Bag.
speech.line: I feare me neuer.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: How farre is it my Lord to Barckly now?

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Beleeue me noble Lord,
I am a ﬅranger in Gloceﬅerſhire,
Theſe high wild hils and rough vneuen wayes,
Drawes out our miles, and makes them weariſome,
And yet your faire diſcourſe hath beene as ſugar,
Making the hard way ſweete and deleƈtable:
But I bethinke me what a weary way,
From Rauenſpurgh to Cotſhall will be found,
In Roﬀe and Willoughby wanting your company,
Which I proteﬅ hath very much beguild
The tediouſneﬀe and proceﬀ of my trauell:
But theirs is ſweetened with the hope to haue
The preſent benefite that I poﬀeﬀe,
And hope to ioy is little leﬀe in ioy,
Then hope inioyed: by this the weary Lords
Shall make their way ſeeme ſhort, as mine hath done,
By ﬁght of what I haue, your noble companie.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Of much leﬀe value is my company,
Then your good words. But who comes here?

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: It is my ſonne, yong Harry Perﬁe,
Sent from my brother Worceﬅer whenceſoeuer:
Harry, how fares your Vnckle?

speech.speaker: H. Per.
speech.line: I had thought my Lord to haue learned his health of you.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Why? is he not with the Queene?

speech.speaker: H. Per.
speech.line: No my good Lord, he hath forſooke the Court,
Broken his ﬅaffe of office, and diſperﬅ
The houſhold of the King.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: What was his reaſon? he was not ſo reſolude,
When laﬅ we ſpake together.

speech.speaker: H. Per.
speech.line: Becauſe your Lordſhip was proclaimed traytour;
But he my Lord, is gone to Rauenſpurgh,
To offer ſeruice to the Duke of Herford,
And ſent me ouer by Barckly to diſcouer,
What power the duke of Yorke had leuied there,
Then with direƈtions; to repaire to Rauenſpurgh.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Haue you forgot the duke of Herford, boy?

speech.speaker: H. Per.
speech.line: No my good Lord for that is not forgot
Which ne’re I did remember, to my knowledge
I neuer in my life did looke on him.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Then learne to know him now, this is the Duke.

speech.speaker: H. Per.
speech.line: My gratious Lord, I tender you my ſeruice,
Such as it is, being tender, raw, and young,
Which elder dayes ſhall ripen and confirme
To more approued ſeruice and deſert.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: I thanke thee gentle Perﬁe, and be ſure,
I count my ſelfe in nothing elſe ſo happy,
As in a ſoule remembring my good friends:
And as my fortune ripens with thy loue,
It ſhall be ﬅill thy true loues recompence,
My heart this couenant makes, my hand thus ſeales it.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: How farre is it to Barkely, and what ﬅurre
Keepes good old Yorke there with his men of warre?

speech.speaker: H. Per.
speech.line: There ﬅandes the Caﬅle by yon tuft of trees,
Mann’d with three hundred men, as I haue heard:
And in it are the Lordes of Yorke, Barkley, and Seymor,
None elſe of name, and noble eﬅimation.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Here come the Lords of Roﬀe and Willoughby,
Bloudy with ſpurring, fiery red with haﬅe.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Welcome my Lords, I wot your loue purſues
A baniſht traitour: all my treaſury
Is yet but vnfelt thankes, vvhich more enricht,
Shall be your loue and labours recompence.

speech.speaker: Roße.
speech.line: Your preſence makes vs rich, moﬅ noble Lord.

speech.speaker: Will.
speech.line: And farre ſurmounts our labour to attaine it.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Euermore thankes the Exchequer of the poore,
Which till my infant fortune comes to yeares,
Standes for my bounty: but vvho comes heere?

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: It is my Lord of Barkeley, as I guﬀe.

speech.speaker: Barkeley.
speech.line: My Lord of Hereford, my meﬀage is to you.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: My Lord, my anſvvere is to Lancaﬆter,
And I am come to ſeeke that name in England,
And I muﬅ finde that title in your tongue,
Before I make reply to ought you ſay.

speech.speaker: Barke.
speech.line: Miﬅake me not my Lord, t’is not my meaning
To race one title of your Honour out:
To you my Lord I come, what Lord you will,
From the moﬅ glorious of this land,
The Duke of Yorke, to know what prickes you on,
To take aduantage of the abſent time,
And fright our natiue peace with ſelfe-borne Armes?

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: I ſhall not need tranſport my words by you,
Heere comes his Grace in perſon: My noble Vnckle!

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Shew me thy humble heart, and not thy knee,
Whoſe duety is deceiueable and falſe.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: My gracious Vnckle!

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Tut, tut, grace me no grace, nor vnckle me no vnckle,
I am no Traitors vnckle; and that word Grace
In an vngratious mouth, is but prophane:
Why haue thoſe baniſht and forbidden legs
Darde once to touch a duﬅ of Englands ground?
But more than why? Why haue they darde to march
So many myles vpon her peacefull boſome,
Fryting her pale-facde Villages with Warre,
And oﬅentation of deſpiſed Armes?
Comﬅ thou becauſe th’annoynted King is hence?
Why fooliſh boy, the King is left behind,
And in my loyall boſome lyes his power:
Were I but now Lord of ſuch hot youth,
As when braue Gaunt thy father, and thy ſelfe,
Reſcued the blacke Prince that young Mars of men,
From foorth the ranckes of many thouſands French,
O then how quickly ſhould this arme of mine,
Now priſoner to the Paulſey, chaﬅiſe thee,
And miniﬅer correƈtion to thy fault!

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: My gratious Vnckle, let me know my fault,
On what condition ﬅands it, and wherein?

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Euen in condition of the worﬅ degree,
In groﬀe rebellion, and deteﬅed treaſon:
Thou art a baniﬅ man, and heere art come,
Before the expiration of thy time,
In brauing armes againﬅ my Soueraigne.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: As I was baniſht, I was baniſht Herford,
But as I come, I come for Lancaﬅer:
And noble Vnckle, I beſeech your Grace,
Looke on my wrongs with an indifferent eye:
You are my Father, or me thinkes in you
I ſee old Gaunt aliue. Oh then Father,
Will you permit that I ſhall ﬅand condemn’d
A wandering Vagabond, my rights and royalties
Pluckt from my Armes perforce, and giuen away
To vpﬅart Vnthrifts? wherefore was I borne?
If that my Cooﬁn King be King of England,
It muﬅ be graunted I am Duke of Lancaﬅer:
You haue a Sonne, Aumerle, my noble Cooﬁn,
Had you firﬅ died, and he been thus trod downe,
He ſhould haue found his Vnckle Gaunt a father,
To rouze his wronges, and chaſe them to the Bay
I am denied to ſue my liuerie heere,
And yet my letters pattents giue me leaue.
My fathers goodes are all diﬅrain’d and ſold,
And theſe, and all, are all amiﬀe employed.
What would you haue me doe? I am a Subieƈt,
And I challenge Law; Atturnies are denide me,
And therefore perſonally I lay my claime
To my inheritance of free deſcent.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: The noble Duke hath been too much abuſde.

speech.speaker: Roße.
speech.line: It ﬅandes your Grace vpon, to do him right.

speech.speaker: Willough.
speech.line: Baſe men by his endowments are made great.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: My Lords of England, let me tell you this;
I haue had feeling of my Cooﬁns wronges,
And laboured all I could to doe him right;
But in this kind, to come in brauing Armes,
Be his owne caruer, and cut out his way,
To find out right with wrong, it may not be:
And you that do abette him in this kind,
Cheriſh Rebellion, and are Rebels all.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: The noble Duke hath ſworne, his comming is
But for his owne; and for the right of that,
We all haue ﬅrongly ſworne to giue him ayde:
And let him ne’re ſee ioy that breakes that oath.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Well, well, I ſee the iﬀue of theſe Armes;
I cannot mende it, I muﬅ needes confeﬀe,
Becauſe my power is weake, and all ill left:
But if I could, by him that gaue my life,
I would attach you all, and make you ﬅoope
Vnto the ſoueraigne mercy of the King:
But ﬁnce I cannot, be it knowne to you,
I do remaine as newter; ſo fare you well,
Vnleﬀe you pleaſe to enter in the Caﬅle,
And there repoſe you for this night.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: An offer Vnckle that we will accept,
But we muﬅ winne your Grace to go with vs
To Briﬅow Caﬅle, which they ſay is held
By Buſhie, Bagot, and their complices,
The Caterpillers of the Common-wealth;
Which I haue ſworne to weede and plucke away.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: It may be I will go with you; but yet Ile pauſe,
For I am loth to breake our Countries Lawes:
Nor friends, nor foes, to me welcome you are,
Things paﬅ redreﬀe, are now with me paﬅ care.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Earle of Salisburie, and a Welch Captaine.

speech.speaker: Welch.
speech.line: My Lord of Salisburie, we haue ﬅaide ten dayes,
And hardly kept our Countrymen together;
And yet we heare no tidings from the King,
Therefore we will diſperſe our ſelues: farewell.

speech.speaker: Saliſ.
speech.line: Stay yet another day, thou truﬅy Welchman,
The King repoſeth all his confidence in thee.

speech.speaker: Welch.
speech.line: Tis thought the King is dead, we will not ﬅay
The Bay-trees in out Countrey all are withered,
And Meteors fright the fixed Starres of heauen:
The pale-fac’d Moone lookes bloody on the earth,
And leane-look’t Prophets whiſper fearefull change,
Rich men looke ſadde, and Ruffians daunce and leape,
The one in feare to looſe what they enioy.
The other to enioy by rage and Warre.
Theſe ﬁgnes fore-run the death of Kinges.
Farewell, our Countrymen are gone and fled,
As well aﬀured Richard their King is dead.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: Ah Richard! with eyes of heauy minde,
I ſee thy glory like a ſhooting ﬅarre,
Fall to the baſe earth from the firmament,
Thy ſunne ſets, weeping in the lowly Weﬅ,
Witneﬃng ﬅormes to come, woe and vnreﬅ:
Thy friendes are fled to waite vpon thy foes,
And croﬀely to thy good all fortune goes.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Duke of Herford, Yorke, Northumberland, Buſhie and Greene Priſoners.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Bring forth theſe men.
Buſhie and Greene, I will not vexe your ſoules,
Since preſently your ſoules muﬅ part your bodies,
With too much vrging your pernicious liues,
For t’were no charity; yet to waſh your blood
From off my hands, here in the view of men,
I will vnfold ſome cauſes of your death,
You haue miſ-led a Prince, a royall King,
A happy Gentleman in blood and lineaments,
By you vnhappied and disfigured cleane,
You haue in manner with your ﬁnfull houres,
Made a diuorce betwixt his Queene and him,
Broke the poﬀeﬃon of a royall bed,
And ﬅaynde the beutie of a fayre Queenes cheekes,
With teares drawne from her eyes with your foule wrongs,
My ſelfe a Prince by fortune of my birth,
Neere to the King in blood, and neere in loue,
Till they did make him miſ-interpret me,
Haue ﬅoopt my necke vnder your iniuries,
And ﬁgh’d my Engliſh breath in forren cloudes,
Eating the bitter bread of baniſhment,
While you haue fedde vpon my ſegniories,
Diſparkt my Parkes, and felld my forreﬅ woods,
From mine owne windowes torne my houſhold coate,
Rac’t out my impreeſe, leauing me no ﬁgne,
Saue mens opinions, and my liuing blood,
To ſhew the world I am a Gentleman.
This, and much more, much more then twice all this,
Condemns you to the death: ſee them deliuered ouer
To execution and the hand of death.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: More welcome is the ﬅroke of death to me,
Then Bullingbrooke to England: Lords farewell.

speech.speaker: Greene.
speech.line: My comfort is, that heauen will take our ſoules,
And plague iniuﬅice with the paines of hell.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: My Lord Northumberland, ſee them diſpatcht:
Vnckle, you ſay, the Queene is at your houſe,
For Gods ſake fairely let her be intreated,
Tell her, I ſend to her my kind commends;
Take ſpeciall care my greetings be deliuered.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: A Gentleman of mine I haue diſpatcht,
With letters of your loue to her at large,

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Thankes (gentle Vnckle:) come Lords, away,
To fight with Glendor and his complices,
A while to worke, and after, holiday.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Barkloughly Caﬅle call you this at hand?

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Yea my Lord; how brook’s your Grace the ayre
After your late toſsing on the breaking Seas?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Needs muﬅ I like it well, I weepe for ioy,
To ﬅand vpon my Kingdome once againe.
Deare earth, I do ſalute thee with my hand,
Though Rebels wound thee with their Horſes hoofes:
As a long parted mother with her child,
Playes fondly with her teares and ſmiles in meeting:
So weeping, ſmiling, greete I thee my earth,
And do thee fauour with my royall hands;
Feede not thy Soueraignes foe, my gentle earth,
Nor with thy ſweetes comfort his rauenous ſence,
But let thy Spiders that ſucke vp thy venome,
And heauy gated Toads lie in their way,
Doing annoyance to the trecherous feete,
Which with vſurping ﬅeps do trample thee:
Yeeld ﬅinging nettles to mine enemies:
And when they from thy boſome plucke a flower,
Guard it I pray thee with a lurking Adder,
Whoſe double tongue may with a mortall touch,
Throw death vpon thy Soueraines enemies:
Mocke not my ſenﬂeﬀe coniuration Lords:
This earth ſhall haue a feeling, and that’e ﬅones
Prooue armed Souldiers ere her natiue King
Shall falter vnder foule rebellious armes.

speech.speaker: Carl:
speech.line: Feare not my Lord, that power that made you King
Hath power to keepe you king in ſpite of all;
The meanes that heauens yeeld muﬅ be imbrac’t
And not neglected.Elſe heauen would,
And we would not, heauens offer, we refuſe
The proffered meanes of ſuccours and redreﬀe.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: He meanes, my Lord, that we are to remiﬀe,
Whilﬅ Bullingbrooke, through our ſecurity,
Growes ﬅrong and great in ſubﬅance and in power.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Diſcomfortable cooﬁn, knowﬅ thou not,
That when the ſearching eie of heauen is hid
Behind the globe that lights the lower world,
Then theeues and robbers range abroade vnſeene,
In murthers, and in outrage bloody heere.
But when from vnder his terreﬅriall ball,
He fires the proude tops of the eﬅerne pines,
And darts his light through euery guilty hole;
Then murders, treaſons, and deteﬅed ﬁnnes,
The cloake of night being pluckt from off their backes,
Stand bare and naked trembling at themſelues:
So when this thiefe, this traitour Bullingbrooke,
Who all this while hath reueld in the night
Whilﬅ we were wandring with the Antipodes,
Shall ſee vs riﬁng in our throne the Eaﬅ,
His treaſons will ﬁt bluſhing in his face,
Not able to endure the ﬁght of day,
But ſelfe affrighted, trembled at his ﬁnne,
Not all the water in the rough rude Sea,
Can waſh the balme off from an annoynted King.
The breath of worldly men cannot depoſe
The deputy eleƈted by the Lord,
For euery man that Bullingbrooke hath preﬅ,
To lift ſhrewde ﬅeele againﬅ our golden crowne,
God for his Ric: hath in heauenly pay,
A glorious Angel: then if Angels fight,
Weake men muﬅ fall, for heauen ﬅill guardes the right.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Welcome my Lord: how farre off lies your power?

speech.speaker: Saliſb.
speech.line: Nor neere nor farther off, my gratious Lord:
Than this weake arme; diſcomfort guides my tongue.
And bids me ſpeake of nothing but Deſpaire,
One day too late, I feare, my noble Lo:
Hath clouded all thy happy dayes on earth,
O call backe yeﬅerday, bid Time returne,
And thou ſhalt haue twelue thouſand fighting men:
To day, to day, vnhappy day, too late,
Ouerthrowes thy ioyes, friends, fortune and thy ﬅate:
For all the Welckmen hearing thou wert dead,
Are gone to Bulingbrooke, diſperﬅ, and fled.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Comfort, my liege, why lookes your Grace ſo pale?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But now the bloud of twenty thouſand men
Did triumph in my face, and they are fled:
And till ſo much bloud thither come againe,
Haue I not reaſon to looke pale and dead?
All ſoules that will be ſafe, flie from my ﬁde,
For Time hath ſet a blot vpon my pride.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Comfort, my Liege, remember who you are.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I had forgot my ſelfe, Am I not King?
Awake thou coward, Maieﬅie thou ﬂeepeﬅ,
Is not the Kings name twentie thouſand names?
Arme, arme, my name a puny ſuieƈt ﬅrikes
At thy great glory, looke not to the ground,
Yee fauorites of a King, are we not high?
High be our thoughts, I know my vnckle Yorke
Hath power euough to ſerue our turne: but who comes heere?

speech.speaker: Scroope.
speech.line: More health and happineﬀe betide my Liege,
Then can my care tunde tongue deliuer him.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Mine eare is open, and my heart prepard,
The worﬅ is worldly loﬀe thou canﬅ vnfold.
Say, is my Kingdome loﬅ? Why twas my care,
And what loﬀe is it to be rid of care?
Striues Bullingbrooke to be as great as we?
Greater he ſhall not be: if he ſerue God,
Weele ſerue him too, and be his fellow ſo.
Reuolt our Subieƈtes? that we can not mende,
They breake their fayth to God as well as vs:
Cry woe, deﬅruƈtion, ruine, and decay,
The worﬅ is death, and dead will haue his day.

speech.speaker: Scroo.
speech.line: Glad am I, that your Highneﬀe is ſo armde
To beare the tydings of calamitie,
Like an vnſeaſonable ﬅormie day,
Which make the ﬁuer Riuers drowne their ſhores.
As if the world were all diﬀolude by teares,
So high aboue his limits ſwels the rage
Of Bullingbrooke, couering your fearefull land
With hard bright ﬅeele, and hearts harder then ﬅeele:
White beards haue armd their thinne and haireleﬀe ſcalps
Againﬅ thy Maieﬅie: and boyes with womens voyces
Striue to ſpeake bigge, and clap their female ioynts
In ﬅiffe vnwildie armes, againﬅ thy Crowne,
Thy very beadſ-men learne to bend their browes,
Of double fatall woe againﬅ thy ﬅate.
Yea diﬅaffe women mannage ruﬅie billes:
Againﬅ thy ſeate both young and old rebell,
And all goes worſe then I haue power to tell.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: To well, to well, thou telﬅ a tale ſo ill.
Where is the Earle of Wiltſhire? where is Bagot?
What is become of Buſhie? where is Greene?
That they haue let the dangerous enemie
Meaſure our confines with ſuch peacefull ﬅeps.
If we preuaile, their heads ſhall pay for it:
I warrant they haue made peace with Bullingbrooke.

speech.speaker: Scro.
speech.line: Peace haue they made with him indeede my Lord.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Oh villaines, vipers, damnd without redemption,
Dogs eaﬁly wonne to fawne on any man.
Snakes in my heart bloud warmd, that ﬅing my heart;
Three Iudaﬀes, each one thrice worſe then Iudas,
Would they make peace? terrible hell
Make warre vpon their ſpotted ſoules for this.

speech.speaker: Scro.
speech.line: Sweet loue’s (I ſee) changing: his property
Turnes to the ſowreﬅ and moﬅ deadly hate.
Againe vncurſe their ſoules, their peace is made,
With head, and not with hands, thoſe whom you curſe
Haue felt the worﬅ of deaths deﬅroying wound,
And lie full low grau’d in the hollow ground.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Is Buſhie, Greene, and the Earle of Wiltſhire dead?

speech.speaker: Sc o.
speech.line: Yea, all of them at Briﬅow loﬅ their heads.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Where is the Duke my father with his power?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: No matter where, of comfort no man ſpeake.
Lets talke of graues, of wormes, and Epitaphs,
Make duﬅ our paper, and with ranie eyes
Write ſorrow on the boſome of the earth.
Lets chooſe Executors and talke of wils:
And yet not ſo, for what can we bequeath,
Saue our depoſed bodies to the ground?
Our lands, our liues, and all are Bullingbrooks,
And nothing can we call our owne, but death,
And that ſmall modell of the barren earth,
Which ſerues as paﬅe and couer to our bones.
For Gods ſake let vs ﬁt vpon the ground,
And tell ſad ﬅories of the death of Kings,
How ſome haue beene depoſde, ſome ﬂaine in war,
Some haunted by the ghoﬅs they haue depoſed,
Some poyſoned by their wives, ſome ﬂeeping kild,
All murthered: for within the hollow Crowne
That rounds the mortall temples of a King,
Keepes death his court, and there the antique ﬁts,
Scoffing his ﬅate, and grinning at his pompe,
Allowing him a breath, a little ſceane,
To Monarchiſe, be feard, and kill with lookes,
Infuﬁng him with ſelfe and vaine conceit,
As if this fleſh which walkes a bout our life,
Were Braﬀe impregnable: and humord thus,
Comes at the laﬅ, and with a lettle pin,
Bores through his Caﬅle walles, and farewell King.
Couer your heades, and mocke not fleſh and blood,
With ſolemne reuerence throw away reſpeƈt,
Tradition, forme, and ceremonious dutie,
For you haue but miﬅooke me all this while,
I liue with bread like you, feele want,
Taﬅe griefe, need friends: ſubieƈted thus,
How can you ſay to mee, I am a Kin?

speech.speaker: Carl.
speech.line: My Lord, Wiſe-men ne’re ﬁt and waile their woes
But preſently preuent the wayes to wayle,
To feare the foe, ﬁnce feare oppreﬀeth ﬅrength,
Giues in your weakeneﬀe ﬅrength vnto your foe,
And ſo your follies fight againﬅ your ſelfe:
Feare, and be ﬂaine, no worſe can come to fight:
And fight and die, is death deﬅroying death,
Where fearing dying, payes death ſeruile breath.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: My Father hath a power, inquire of him,
And learne to make a body of a limme.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thou chidﬅ me well; proud Bullingbrooke, I come,
To change blowes with thee for our day of doome:
This Ague-fit of feare is ouerblowne,
An eaﬁe taske it is to winne our owne.
Say Scroope, Where lies our Vnckle with his power?
Speake ſweetely man, although thy lookes be ſower.

speech.speaker: Scroope.
speech.line: Men iudge by the complexion of the skie,
The ﬅate and inclination of the day;
So may you by my dull and heauy eye:
My tongue hath but a heauier tale to ſay,
I play the torturer by ſmall and ſmall,
To lengthen out the worﬅ that muﬅ be ſpoken:
Your Vnckle Yorke is ioyn’d with Bullingbrooke,
And all your Northerne Caﬅles yeelded vp,
And all your Southerne Gentlemen in armes
Vpon his partie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thou haﬅ ſayd enough:
Beſhrew thee Cooﬁn which didﬅ lead me foorth
Of that ſweete way I was in to diſpaire.
What ſay you now? What comfort haue we now?
By heauen Ile hate him euerlaﬅingly,
That bids me be of comfort any more,
Goe to Flint Caﬅle, there Ile pine away,
A King woes ﬂaue, ſhall kingly woe obey:
That power I haue; diſcharge, and let them go
To eare the land that hath ſome hope to grow:
For I haue none; let no man ſpeake againe
To alter this, for counſell is but vaine.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: My Liege one word.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: He does me double wrong,
That wounds me with the flatteries of his tongue:
Diſcharge my followers, let them hence away,
From Richards night, to Bullingbrooks faire day.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: So that by this intelligence we learne,
The Welchmen are diſpearﬅ, and Salisbury
Is gone to meete the King, who lately landed
With ſome few priuate friends, vpon this coaﬅ.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: The newes is very faire and good, my Lord
Richard not farre from hence hath hid his head.

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: It would beſeeme the Lord Northumberland,
To ſay, King Richard; alacke the heauie day,
When ſuch a ſacred King, ſhould hide his head.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Your Grace miﬅakes; onely to be briefe,
Left I his title out.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: The time hath bin, ſhould you haue bin ſo briefe with him,
He would haue bin ſo briefe to ſhorten you,
For taking ſo the head, your whole heads length.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Miﬅake not (Vnckle) further then you ſhould.

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: Take not (good Cooﬁn) further then you ſhould,
Leaﬅ you miﬅake the heauens are ouer your heads.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: I know it Vnckle, and oppoſe not my ſelfe
Againﬅ their willes. But who comes heere?
Welcome Harry: What, will not this Caﬅle yeeld?

speech.speaker: H. Percie.
speech.line: The Caﬅle is royally mand my Lord.
Againﬅ thy entrance.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Royally, why it containes no King.

speech.speaker: H. Per.
speech.line: Yes (my good Lord)
It doth containe a King, King Richard lies
Within the limits of yon lime and ﬅone,
